By using density functional theory calculation, we investigated the CO2 reduction to CH4 on molybdenum-doped graphene (Mo@Gra) and identified two major paths from the HCOO* and COOH* intermediates with different onset potential. Both HCOO* and COOH* would continent hydrogenating to CH4 by an eight proton-electron coupling transfer process via HCOO path and COOH path. By the HCOO path, the formation of HCOO* is exergonic and the potential determining step (PDS) is OH* to H2O* by an endergonic process of 0.70 eV. On the other hand, the formation of COOH* from CO2* is endergonic with the same PDS and a limiting potential (UL) of –0.70 V. In addition, nitrogen coordinated Mo-graphene (Mo@3N-Gra) also illustrated for CO2 reduction and the corresponding UL is found to be –1.88 V. In addition, we also explore the mechanisms of CO2 reduction on the water pre-adsorption surface for realistic experiments. The UL required to overcome was reduced to –0.25 V for 3H2O*Mo@Gra with three H2O co-adsorption environment, suggesting the catalytic performance can be enhanced by water promotion effect. Two structures of hydrated structures, 2H2O*OH*Mo@3N-Gra and 3H2O*Mo@3N-Gra, were selected for stimulate realistic experiments. Compared to the Mo@3N-Gra catalyst, the UL reduces to –0.48 and –0.70 V for 2H2O*OH*Mo@3N-Gra and 3H2O*Mo@3N-Gra, respectively. Although, Mo-N doped graphene has better CO2 capture ability and selectivity, it needs more onset potential to produce CH4. Our calculations demonstrated that the electrocatalytic performance can be enhanced by the hydration effect. Graphical abstract Electrochemical CO2 Reduction on Mo Single-Atom Catalyst and Its Hydrate Image, graphical abstract Keywords Electrochemical CO2 reduction Electrocatalysis Mo-doped graphene Single-metal catalysts DFT calculations Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction In recent years, extensive use of fossil resources and the combustion of their products have led to significant releases of CO2 into the atmosphere and oceans. This has exacerbated the greenhouse effect and ocean acidification, further degrading environmental conditions [1–3]. To address the rapid depletion of non-renewable resources and associated environmental issues, many scientists have focused on developing methods to store renewable energy by converting electrical energy into chemical energy [4]. The CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) has been recognized as an ideal approach to converting CO2 into useful fuels, such as formic acid, methane, methanol, and ethylene, using renewable energy sources [5–10]. In the past, studies primarily focused on metal catalysts, which required high overpotentials and exhibited low Faradaic efficiencies [11–14]. Recently, however, heterogeneous single-atom catalysts (SACs) have emerged as a significant area of interest in catalysis science and technology [15–31]. In 2009, Zhang, Li, Liu, and colleagues first prepared and characterized a practical catalyst with Pt single atoms dispersed on iron oxides, denoted as Pt1/FeOx, which showed high activity for CO oxidation and preferential oxidation of CO [13,32,33]. Unlike traditional nanocatalysts, feature individual and isolated metal atoms anchored on specific supports, maximizing atom utilization efficiency without obvious interactions between metal atoms [34–38]. The supports used in SACs include metal oxides [33,39–41], metal sulfides [42], graphene [32,43,44], C3N4 [45,46], metal-organic frameworks, and etc. This article specifically utilizes graphene as a carrier; it has numerous applications in electrocatalysis, such as in oxygen reduction, nitrogen reduction, carbon dioxide reduction reactions, and the oxidation of methanol, ethanol, and formic acid. Current research on SACs in electrocatalysis mainly focuses on selectivity—owing to the lack of metal-metal bonds, which may alter reaction pathways compared to nanopowder catalysts—and on activity and stability, as interactions between different single atoms and their supports can significantly alter the electronic structure, impacting electrochemical activity and stability. Graphene, as a carbon material, has been widely studied in catalysis and other fields. It is a single-layer two-dimensional (2D) sheet of sp2 bonded carbon atoms with a high surface area, superior thermal conductivity (exceeding that of carbon nanotubes and diamonds), and high electron mobility, which contribute to its low electrical resistance. These properties make it an ideal conductive support to anchor electrocatalysts and regulate electrochemical reactions in a controlled manner [47,48]. However, pristine graphene's flat surface lacks specific sites for metal atom adsorption, leading to potential metal clustering unless chemically modified to enhance activity by introducing functional groups. To enhance catalytic activity, single-atom catalysts can also improve the intrinsic activity of the original active site, for example, by altering the electrophilicity and nucleophilicity. Introducing elements such as nitrogen around the metal atom can increase the electrophilicity and enhance charge transfer [49–51]. The transition metal–nitrogen (N) moiety has been proposed to activate catalytic activity in the early stages of research on carbon-based catalysts, despite a lack of systematic understanding of the role of dopants [44]. In this article, we explore the potential of molybdenum doped on single-defect graphene (Mo@Gra) and nitrogen-modified Mo doped graphene (Mo@3N-Gra) as CO2RR electrocatalysts in an aqueous solution environment using density functional theory (DFT) computations. We calculated the Gibbs free energy changes for various intermediates in each elementary step, aiming to identify the lowest positive changes that determine the potential determining step. 2 Computational methods Calculations were carried out by using spin-polarized DFT within the Dmol3 module of Materials Studio [52,53]. Electron interactions were represented by the exchange–correlation functional of Perdew–Burke–Ernzerh (PBE) within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [54]. The empirical correction in Grimme's scheme was utilized to treat the van der Waals interactions between CO2 reduction reaction intermediates and catalysts. We also considered relativistic effects of transition metals through the density functional semi-core pseudopotentials, in which a single effective potential and some degree of relativistic corrections replace the core electrons, while the double numerical plus polarization (DNP) basis set was used for other elements [55]. Self-consistent field calculations were performed with a convergence criterion of 10−6 a.u. for the total energy and electronic calculations [56]. The real-space global orbital cutoff radius was chosen as 4.9 Å during the computations to ensure high quality results. The vacuum space was established at 15 Å to sufficiently prevent interactions between periodic images. The Brillouin zone was sampled using a 5 × 5 × 1 Monkhorst–Pack mesh grid in reciprocal space during geometry optimizations [57]. The adsorption energy (ΔEads) of adsorbates and intermediates in CO2 reduction reaction was calculated by: Δ E ads = E total − ( E catal + E adsorbate ) Etotal was the total energy of adsorbates on the catalyst, Ecatal was the energy of the catalyst, and Eadsorbate was the energy of adsorbates and intermediates. The Gibbs free energies (ΔG) were computed using computational hydrogen electrode model proposed by Nørskov and coworkers [23,58], which can be defined as: Δ G = Δ E + Δ E ZPE − T Δ S + Δ G pH + Δ G U where ΔE represents the reaction or adsorption energy. ΔEZPE and ΔS are the differences of zero-point energy and entropy computed from the vibration frequency calculations. For the adsorbates, the ZPE and S were calculated using the harmonic approximation on the basis of the normal-mode vibrational frequencies, whereas the S of the gas molecules was taken from the National Institute of Standards and Technology database (NIST). Temperature (T) is set to 298.15 K. The pH in the equation of ΔGpH = 2.303 × kBT × pH is established at zero. The ∆GU represents applied electrical potential. U L = − Δ G m a x / e Δ G m a x is the Gibbs free-energy change for the PDS at zero potential, and e is the number of electrons transferred in the PDS. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure stability As depicted in Fig. S1 of the Supporting Information, the unit cell of primitive model, Mo@Gra, was built by depositing a molybdenum atom on single-vacancy defect of a graphene with 31 carbon atoms. The three coordinated carbon atoms are substituted by three nitrogen atoms to generate Mo@3N-Gra sheet. In order to explore the stability of the structure, the dissolution energy and binding energy of the catalysts are calculated by the below equations: U dis = U Mo 0 + [ E Mo , bulk − ( E Mo @ Gra − E Gra ) ] / n e E bind = E Mo @ Gra − E Gra − E Mo , bulk UMo 0 is the standard dissolution potential of metal bulk, EMo,bulk is the total energy of a molybdenum atom in the bulk, EM@Gra is the total energy of metal doped in defective graphene, and EM@Gra is the total energy of defective graphene. ne is the number of electrons participating in the dissolution. Take molybdenum as an example: Mo + 3H+ → Mo3+ + 3/2H2 and ne is 3. A positive value of dissolution energy (Udis) indicates that the catalyst can exist stably, while a negative value indicates that the catalyst can exist stably under an applied voltage. A more negative value of binding energy (Ebind) suggesting that Mo is more strong binding on defective site of the catalyst. As listed in Table 1 , the predicted binding energy for Mo@Gra and Mo@3N-Gra is –0.62 and 2.51 eV, respectively. As seen in Table 1, the Udis for Mo@Gra and Mo@3N-Gra is calculated to be 0.01 and –1.04 V, respectively, indicating the Mo@Gra is more electrochemical stability under electrochemical conditions. Although Mo@3N-Gra has large values of binding energy (2.51 eV) and dissolution energy (–1.04 V), there are also experiments that can synthesize catalysts with negative dissolution energy [59]. 3.2 Hydration of active site In the electrochemical process, CO2 reduction occurs in an aqueous solution. Therefore, we discussed the hydration process of the active central metal by the water molecules. In addition, the extent of hydrolysis occurs for the small and highly charged metal which effectively polar the OH bond of H2O to form OH. The calculated Gibbs free energy (Gads ) of different amounts of H2O* and OH* adsorbed on the Mo@Gra and Mo@3N-Gra catalysts are investigated and displayed in the Fig. 1 . The Gads values are predicted to be –0.81, –1.05, and –1.37 eV for H2O*, 2H2O*, and 3H2O* on the Mo@Gra sheet, while those are –0.89, –1.47, and –2.18 eV for H2O*, 2H2O*, and 3H2O* on the Mo@3N-Gra sheet. The computed Gads values for OH*, 2OH*, and 3OH* on the Mo@Gra are –0.70, –1.36, and –0.77 eV, while those are –1.88, –2.27, and –2.71 eV for the Mo@3N-Gra. The co-adsorption of H2O and OH are also considered. The calculated Gads values for H2O*OH*, 2H2O*OH*, and H2O*2OH* on the Mo@Gra are –1.36, –1.49, and –1.42 eV, while those are –2.13, –2.61, and –2.70 eV for the Mo@3N-Gra. It can be seen that the most stable adsorption structure is OH*+2H2O* on the Mo@Gra, that can be reduced to 3H2O* at a very low potential, –0.12 V. While the most stable adsorption structure is 3OH* on the Mo@3N-Gra, that can be reduced to OH*+2H2O* at –0.09 V but requires related high potential of –0.44 V reducing to 3H2O*. As seen in Table 1, the hydration of 3H2O*Mo@Gra and 3H2O*Mo@3N-Gra become more stable than Mo@Gra and Mo@3N-Gra. The Ebind and Udis are –2.56 eV and 0.65 V for 3H2O*Mo@Gra and those are 0.73 eV and –0.44 V for 3H2O*Mo@3N-Gra and –0.98 eV and 0.13 V for 2H2O*OH*Mo@3N-Gra. Consequently, in the cases of all the 3H2O*Mo@Gra and 2H2O*OH*Mo@3N-Gra catalysts have Ebind 〈 0 and Udis 〉 0, demonstrating their thermodynamic and electrochemical stability. Though an external voltage (–0.44 V) is also required to synthesis the 3H2O*Mo@3N-Gra catalyst, it is much stable than Mo@3N-Gra which can be synthesized experimentally. Therefore, we will study the CO2RR on the pre-adsorption of 3H2O*Mo@Gra and both pre-adsorption of 3H2O*Mo@3N-Gra and 2H2O*OH*Mo@3N-Gra in the following section. 3.3 CO2 reduction reaction pathway After examining the stability of the catalysts, we illustrate the possible routes of CO2RR to generate virous products with different amount of proton-electron group [60,61]. As depicted in Fig. S2, two pathways: formate (HCOO) and carboxyl (COOH) pathway are considered. The first hydrogenation step of CO2 occurs to form HCOO* (formate pathway) and COOH* (carboxyl pathway) adsorbates which is critical and further continues hydrogenating to produce CO, HCOOH, CH3OH,or CH4, etc. In our calculation, the formation of COOH* primarily occurs through the chemisorption of CO2, followed by subsequent hydrogenation onto O atom of CO2 by the process (H + + e –) + CO2 + * → (H + + e –) + CO2* →COOH*. As seen in Fig. 2 , the charge redistribution shown that the CO2* with negative charge in O atoms which easily to accept the H +to produce COOH*. While the formation mechanisms of HCOO* intermediate through the chemisorption of H, followed by subsequent hydrogenation onto C atom of CO2 by the process (H + + e –) + CO2 + * → H* + CO2 → HCOO*. The charge redistribution shown that the adsorbed hydrogen forms hydride with negative charge, while the partial charges of Mo become more positive. This charge redistribution results in a favorable electronic configuration that facilitates the acceptance of CO2 to generate HCOO*. As in depicted Fig. 3 , the lowest-energy reaction pathway for the CO2RR via the HCOO route on the Mo@Gra catalyst is illustrated to be * + CO2 + H + + e −→ CO2* +H + + e − → HCOO* → CH2OO* → CH2OOH* → CH2O* → CH3O* →O* + CH4(g)→ OH* → H2O*, the corresponding PDS is the step of OH* → H2O* with a UL of –0.70 V, and its final product is methane. It is noted that there is a less thermodynamically favorable step of CH2O* → CH2OH* → CH3OH* → * + CH3OH(l), indicating that production of CH4(g) is more energetically favorable than CH3OH(l)formation. For the COOH route, the lowest-energy reaction pathway is * + CO2 + H + + e −→ CO2* + H + + e − → COOH* → CO* → CHO* → CH2O* → CH3O* →O* + CH4(g)→ OH* → H2O*, the corresponding PDS is the step of OH* → H2O* with a UL of –0.70 V for the formation CH4. One should notices that the adsorption free energies for CO2* and H* are –0.46 and 0.05 eV, respectively, indicating that CO2 is more easily adsorbed on the Mo@Gra sheet that is beneficial for the CO2RR. For the Mo@3N-Gra catalyst, it has a good performance in capturing CO2 (Gads = –1.53 eV) and H + + e − (Gads = –0.70 eV). The predicted Mo d-band center of Mo@3N-Gra and its hydrate (3H2O*Mo@3N-Gra) are –0.80 and –0.88 eV while those are –2.55 and –2.55 eV for Mo@Gra and 3H2O*Mo@Gra that explains the strong adsorption of CO2 and H + + e − on the Mo@3N-Gra and its hydrate compared to those on the Mo@Gra system (see Figs. S3 ∼ S5). For the 2H2O*OH*@3N-Gra, the low d-band center of –3.41 eV leads to the weak adsorption of CO2 (Gads = –0.19 eV). Similar to the Mo@Gra catalyst, methane can be produced through both the COOH* path and HCOO* path with same intermediates as depicted in Fig. 4 . However, all the intermediates exhibit strangely adsorption on the Mo@3N-Gra than those on the Mo@Gra. The PDS for the both COOH* path and HCOO* path is also the final hydrogenation step of OH* → H2O* with a much larger UL of –1.88 V. Due to the high Gads (–0.81 and –0.89 eV) of H2O and high ΔG of OH* → H2O* (0.70 and 1.88 eV) on the Mo@Gra and Mo@3N-Gra results in competing with CO2 adsorption, we therefore study the CO2RR mechanisms on the H2O and H2O+OH pre-adsorption surfaces for realistic experiments. The pre-adsorption of 3H2O*Mo@Gra and both pre-adsorption of 3H2O*Mo@3N-Gra and 2H2O*OH*Mo@3N-Gra are selected based on the section of hydration of active site. In the hydration 3H2O*Mo@Gra catalyst, as seen in Fig. 5 , the first step takes place by exchanging one H2O* with CO2* with releasing 0.05 eV energy to form 2W*CO2*. Then it undergoes the COOH pathway through CO2 + 3H2O* (CO2(g)3W*) → CO2* + 2H2O* + H + + e − (2W*CO2*) → 2W*COOH* → 2W*CO* → 2W*CHO* → 2W*CH2O* → 2W*CH3O* → 2W*O* + CH4(g)→ 2W*OH* → 3W*, the corresponding PDS is the step of CO2* + 2H2O* + H + + e − (2W*CO2*) → 2W*COOH* with a UL of –0.25 V for the formation CH4. For the HCOO route, the lowest-energy reaction pathway is CO2 + 3H2O* (CO2(g)3W*) + H + + e − → H* + 2H2O* + H + + e − (2W*H*) → 2W*HCOO* → 2W*HCOOH* → 2W*CH2OOH* → 2W*CH2O* → 2W*CH3O* → 2W*O* + CH4(g)→ 2W*OH* → 3W*, the corresponding PDS is the step of 2W*HCOO* → 2W*HCOOH* with a UL of –0.50 V. Compared to the Mo@Gra catalyst, the UL reduces to –0.25 V from –0.70 V. It is instructive to notice that the ΔG of OH* → H2O* decrease to 0.19 eV compared to that (0.70 eV) of pristine Mo@Gra catalyst, indicating the weaker OH adsorption on the 3H2O*Mo@Gra catalyst that leads to a smaller UL. For the hydration 3H2O*Mo@3N-Gra catalyst, as seen in Fig. 6 , the first step takes place by exchanging one H2O* with CO2* with releasing energy of 0.66 eV to form 2W*CO2*. Then it undergoes the COOH pathway through CO2* + 2H2O* + H + + e − (2W*CO2*) → 2W*COOH* → 2W*CO* → 2W*CHO* → 2W*CH2O* → 2W*CH3O* → 2W*O* + CH4(g) → 2W*OH* → 3W*, the corresponding PDS is the step of CO2* + 2H2O* + H + + e − (2W*CO2*) → 2W*COOH* with a UL of –0.75 V for the formation CH4. For the HCOO route, the lowest-energy reaction pathway is CO2 + 3H2O* (CO2(g)3W*) + H + + e − → H* + 2H2O* + H + + e − (2W*H*) → 2W*HCOO* → 2W*CH2OO* → 2W*CH2OOH* → 2W*CH2O* → 2W*CH3O* → 2W*O* + CH4(g)→ 2W*OH* → 3W*, the corresponding PDS is the step of 2W*HCOO* → 2W*CH2OO* with a UL of –0.70 V. Compared to the Mo@3N-Gra catalyst, the UL reduces to –0.70 V from –1.88 V. This is because the ΔG of OH* → H2O* decrease to 0.47 eV compared to that (1.88 eV) of pristine Mo@3N-Gra catalyst, indicating the weaker OH adsorption on the 3H2O*Mo@3N-Gra catalyst that leads to a smaller UL. For the hydration 2H2O*OH*Mo@3N-Gra catalyst, as seen in Fig. 7 , the first step takes place by exchanging one H2O* with CO2* with releasing energy of 0.19 eV to form W*OH*CO2*. Then it undergoes the COOH pathway through CO2* + H2O* + OH* (W*OH*CO2*) → W*OH*COOH* → W*OH*CO* → W*OH*CHO* → W*OH*CH2O* → W*OH*CH3O* → 2 W*OH*O* + CH4(g) → W*OH*OH* → 2W*OH*, the corresponding PDS is the step of W*OH*CO* → W*OH*CHO* with a UL of –0.71 V for the formation CH4. For the HCOO route, the lowest-energy reaction pathway is CO2 + 2H2O*OH* (CO2(g)2W*OH*) + H + + e − → H* + H2O* + OH* + H + + e − (W*OH*H*) → W*OH*HCOO* → W*OH*CH2OO* → W*OH*CH2OOH* → W*OH*CH2O* → W*OH*CH3O* → W*OH*O* + CH4(g)→ W*OH*OH* → 2W*OH*, the corresponding PDS is the step of 2W*OH* → W*OH*H* with a UL of –0.48 V. Compared to the Mo@3N-Gra catalyst, the UL reduces to –0.48 V from –1.88 V and the ΔG of OH* → H2O* decrease to only 0.10 eV compared to that (1.88 eV) of pristine Mo@3N-Gra catalyst, indicating the weaker OH adsorption on the 3H2O*Mo@3N-Gra catalyst that leads to a smaller UL. 3.4 Selectivity of CO2RR The hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) will be a competitive process in acidic condition owing to the strong adsorption between the proton-electron pair (H + + e −) and the TM active site, resulting in poor reaction selectivity for the CO2RR and impedes the faradic efficiency (FE) of the CO2RR. If the TM active site is occupied by the proton-electron pairs during the CO2RR process, the catalyst cannot effectively capture CO2 and limit CO2RR selectivity. Good selectivity is very important for evaluating the performance of a catalyst. The competition between NRR and CO2RR processes on the catalyst can be compared by the predicted ∆GCO2* and ∆GH* , with ∆GCO2* < ∆GH* (∆GCO2* is more negative) indicating that CO2 is more easily occupied on the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 8 and Table 2 , all the catalysts (Mo@Gra and Mo@3N-gra with and without hydration) exhibit strongly adsorption of CO2 than H (∆GCO2* < ∆GH* ), indicating that CO2 is more likely to adsorb the TM active site which facilitates the CO2RR process. In addition, theoretical Faradaic efficiency (FE) of the CO2RR with the competing HER is computed to quantitatively describe the CO2RR selectivity. (details in Supporting Information, Note S1). The value of FE are 59.6 ∼ 99.6% for all the hydrated catalysts (see Table 2). Accordingly, those catalysts exhibit high selectivity for the CO2RR by suppressing the competing HER. 3.5 Scaling relationship for CO2RR descriptors The catalytic activity trend may be closely related to specific structural descriptors. Accordingly, we studied the scaling relationship between the limiting potential and the Mo d-band center, between ΔGCOOH*, and between ΔGHCOO* and a general structure descriptor σ across different catalysts to predict the CO2RR activity of axial coordination ligand SACs. As depicted in Fig. 9 , the linear relationship between limiting potential and the Mo d-band center, indicated by a small R2 = 0.22, is very weak, suggesting that the d-band center is not suitable for screening SACs for CO2RR. To better understand the origins of catalyst activity for CO2RR, we utilized a new descriptor, σ [62]. This descriptor incorporates the number valence electrons of the metal (θv), the electronegativity of the elements, and a correction factor (a Hund) as follows: σ = a ( 19 − 2 θ v ) + a H u n d E M − 0.3 E L 1 + 0.15 n E L 2 ) where a and b are calculation method correction coefficients, set to 1. EM, E L1 and E L2 represent the electronegativity of metal atoms, direct ligand atoms, and indirect ligand atoms, respectively, and n being the number of indirect ligand elements. a Hund is set to –5 for Mo. Compared to the d-band center, there is a stronger linear correlation between σ and ΔGCOOH* with R2 = 0.77 and ΔGHCOO* with R2 = 0.56, as depicted in Fig. 9. These results suggest that the descriptor σ is quite general and effective for predicting the catalytic properties of axial coordination ligand SACs. 4 Conclusions In this study, four SACs catalysis models, Mo@Gra and Mo@3N-Gra with and without hydration, have been investigated their electrocatalytic potential for the process of CO2RR. Both important intermediates, HCOO* and COOH*, would continent hydrogenating to CH4 by an eight proton-electron coupling transfer process via HCOO and COOH pathways. The PDS for CO2RR on both Mo@Gra and Mo@3N-Gra is found to be the final hydrogenation step of OH* → H2O* with a UL of –0.70 and –1.88 V, respectively. In the hydration 3H2O*Mo@Gra catalyst, the PDS is the step of CO2* + 2H2O* + H + + e − (2W*CO2*) → 2W*COOH* with a lower UL of –0.25 V. Compared to the Mo@3N-Gra catalyst, the UL of the hydration 3H2O*Mo@3N-Gra catalyst reduces to –0.70 V from –1.88 V. The ΔG of OH* → H2O* decrease to 0.19 eV and 0.47 for 3H2O*Mo@Gra and 3H2O*Mo@3N-Gra catalysts compared to those (0.70 and 1.88 eV) of pristine Mo@Gra and Mo@3N-Gra catalysts, indicating the weaker OH adsorption on the hydrated catalysts that leads to a smaller UL. The ΔG of OH* → H2O* decrease to 0.47 eV compared to that (1.88 eV) of pristine Mo@3N-Gra catalyst, indicating the weaker OH adsorption on the 3H2O*Mo@3N-Gra catalyst that leads to a smaller UL. For the hydration 2H2O*OH*Mo@3N-Gra catalyst, the corresponding PDS is the step of 2W*OH* → W*OH*H* with a UL of –0.48 V. Compared to the Mo@3N-Gra catalyst, the UL reduces to –0.48 V from –1.88 V and the ΔG of OH* → H2O* decrease to only 0.10 eV compared to that (1.88 eV) of pristine Mo@3N-Gra catalyst. The results demonstrate that the catalytic performance can be enhanced by the hydration effect. Supporting Information The detailed calculation of Faradaic Efficiency of CO2RR. coredata.dc:description: By using density functional theory calculation, we investigated the CO2 reduction to CH4 on molybdenum-doped graphene (Mo@Gra) and identified two major paths from the HCOO* and COOH* intermediates with different onset potential. Both HCOO* and COOH* would continent hydrogenating to CH4 by an eight proton-electron coupling transfer process via HCOO path and COOH path. By the HCOO path, the formation of HCOO* is exergonic and the potential determining step (PDS) is OH* to H2O* by an endergonic process of 0.70 eV. On the other hand, the formation of COOH* from CO2* is endergonic with the same PDS and a limiting potential (UL) of –0.70 V. In addition, nitrogen coordinated Mo-graphene (Mo@3N-Gra) also illustrated for CO2 reduction and the corresponding UL is found to be –1.88 V. In addition, we also explore the mechanisms of CO2 reduction on the water pre-adsorption surface for realistic experiments. The UL required to overcome was reduced to –0.25 V for 3H2O*Mo@Gra with three H2O co-adsorption environment, suggesting the catalytic performance can be enhanced by water promotion effect. Two structures of hydrated structures, 2H2O*OH*Mo@3N-Gra and 3H2O*Mo@3N-Gra, were selected for stimulate realistic experiments. Compared to the Mo@3N-Gra catalyst, the UL reduces to –0.48 and –0.70 V for 2H2O*OH*Mo@3N-Gra and 3H2O*Mo@3N-Gra, respectively. Although, Mo-N doped graphene has better CO2 capture ability and selectivity, it needs more onset potential to produce CH4. Our calculations demonstrated that the electrocatalytic performance can be enhanced by the hydration effect.
